quote: I have used ChatGPT to write cover letters and update my resume about a year ago when I was looking for a job.
I had heard a friend used AI for recipe ideas, so I just typed in toddler-friendly meals because I'm a mom. I haven't tried it for adult meals yet, but I am intrigued by the idea.
I had seen on social media that this was something you could do to create a customized coloring book.

I was actually kind of pleased that it rejected my photo because it was one that I hadn't considered inappropriate. It was a picture of my daughter using the potty, which I thought would be fun to turn into a coloring page, but it never occurred to me that it was inappropriate.
I am a little old school and a bit nervous about using AI exclusively. I always like to double-check that it's accurate, both in work and outside of work.
I would be interested in continuing to use it for work, but I also have concerns that it might replace me.
I don't yet have a full grasp of what it could do.
It can't drive a car, it can't take care of my child, and it can't buy groceries for me. So I think right now, I'm just enjoying its current capabilities.
I would be worried about errors, so I would want to double-check things. I would prefer to approve items before they automatically go to email or send a calendar invite.
AI is also interconnected with some of the tools that I use for work, like video editing and transcription, which I love.
I really liked how the AI was dynamic and how it provided customized questions based on my previous responses. That was pretty cool.

I think I was just kind of frustrated because I didn't have a good answer, and I would have liked it if it was a human who could have pivoted and maybe asked something else. So, it felt a little bit limiting, but I don't think the stakes were very high here, so it didn't matter ... It could be a bigger issue if I was interviewing for a job or in a work meeting with a client.
a better question would have been, "What are some tasks that are really time-consuming and arduous in your life today?" Something less direct and more indirect.
